feed.title: Current Watches, Warnings and Advisories for the United States Issued by the National Weather Service

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued February 13 at 7:03PM AKST until February 14 at 6:00AM AKST by NWS
entry.summary: ...WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 6 AM AKST MONDAY... * WHAT...Snow and blowing snow with low visibility occurring. Plan on difficult travel conditions. Additional snow accumulations up to one inch expected. Visibility one half mile or less at times.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Yukon Flats and Surrounding Uplands

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued February 13 at 3:51PM AKST by NWS
entry.summary: ...TWO WINTER STORMS EXPECTED TO IMPACT SOUTHCENTRAL THROUGHOUT THE WEEK.... The active weather pattern will continue as the new work week progresses. The first system is expected to move through Southcentral Monday afternoon through Tuesday. Expect precipitation in the form of snow for all areas with snow
entry.cap:areaDesc: Anchorage; Copper River Basin; Matanuska Valley; Northeast Prince William Sound; Southeast Prince William Sound; Susitna Valley; Western Kenai Peninsula; Western Prince William Sound

entry.summary: ...WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM 7 PM MONDAY TO NOON AKST TUESDAY... * WHAT...Snow expected. Total snow accumulations of 4 to 6 inches. * WHERE...Yakutat Area. * WHEN...From 7 PM Monday to noon AKST Tuesday.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Cape Fairweather to Cape Suckling Coastal Area

entry.title: Wind Chill Warning issued February 13 at 2:43PM AKST until February 14 at 6:00PM AKST by NWS
entry.summary: ...WIND CHILL WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 6 PM AKST MONDAY... * WHAT...Dangerously cold wind chills 60 to 70 below occuring. The cold wind chills will cause frostbite in as little as 10 minutes to exposed skin. * WHERE...Central Beaufort Sea Coast. * WHEN...Now to 6 PM Monday.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Central Beaufort Sea Coast

entry.summary: ...BLIZZARD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 5 AM AKST MONDAY... * WHAT...Blizzard conditions occurring. Total snow accumulations of 2 to 4 inches. entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued February 13 at 1:44PM PST by NWS
entry.summary: ...A Brief Return to Winter Monday Evening into Tuesday Morning... A fast moving slider-type low pressure system will move across eastern California and western Nevada Monday evening into early Tuesday morning. This will bring an increase in winds Monday afternoon into Monday night, with colder conditions and a short period of rain and snow Monday evening through early Tuesday.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Greater Lake Tahoe Area; Lassen-Eastern Plumas-Eastern Sierra Counties; Mono; Surprise Valley California

entry.summary: ...A Brief Return to Winter Monday Evening into Tuesday Morning... entry.summary: ...HIGH RIP CURRENT RISK REMAINS IN EFFECT THROUGH TUESDAY AFTERNOON... * WHAT...Dangerous rip currents expected due to breaking waves of 6 to 8 feet. * WHERE...Most beaches of Saint Croix. * WHEN...Through Tuesday afternoon. * IMPACTS...Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away
entry.cap:areaDesc: St Croix

entry.summary: ...WIND CHILL ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 10 AM EST THIS MORNING... * WHAT...Very cold wind chills expected. Wind chills as low as 15 below zero. * WHERE...Southeast Randolph and Northwest Pocahontas Counties. * WHEN...Until 10 AM EST Monday.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued February 14 at 3:29AM EST by NWS
entry.summary: Early morning snowfall may have created some slick spots to roadways, especially if left untreated. Even though snowfall amounts were minimal, along with below freezing temperatures, any leftover moisture will have froze overnight and could also add to possible hazardous spots. The snow may continue into the morning commute in certain areas

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued February 14 at 3:15AM EST by NWS
entry.summary: ...Scattered Snow Showers Expected Through Daybreak... An upper-level disturbance and a fresh surge of Canadian air was moving southeast across the region tonight. This has resulted in the development of scattered snow showers across southeastern West Virginia southeast into the Roanoke Valley, the New River Valley, and adjacent areas west to around the Interstate 77 corridor. Snow

entry.title: High Wind Watch issued February 13 at 2:41PM MST until February 14 at 8:00PM MST by NWS
entry.summary: ...HIGH WIND WATCH REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM MONDAY MORNING THROUGH MONDAY EVENING... ...HIGH WIND WARNING IS CANCELLED... * WHAT...West winds 30 to 40 mph with gusts up to 65 mph possible. * WHERE...North Snowy Range Foothills, including Interstate 80 between Laramie and Rawlins.
